summary: This is a government memorandum filed in the Southern District of New York opposing Ghislaine Maxwell's renewed motion for pretrial release on bail. It argues she remains an extreme flight risk due to the seriousness of the charges, strength of evidence, her extensive foreign ties, significant financial resources, and demonstrated ability to live in hiding. The document references the court's prior detention order from July 14, 2020.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Charged with facilitating the sexual abuse of minor victims by Jeffrey Epstein between 1994 and 1997, and with perjury. The government argues she is a severe flight risk and should remain detained.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier with whom Maxwell allegedly conspired to entice and transport minors for illegal sex acts. His will reportedly includes a $10 million grant to Maxwell.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Signing attorney for the government's memorandum opposing Maxwell's bail motion.

persons.name: Scott Borgerson
persons.context: Referred to as Maxwell's spouse. The document notes inconsistent statements about their marital status and that Maxwell transferred significant assets to him over five years.

persons.name: Hans Peterson
persons.context: Cited as an example of a dual U.S.-French citizen whom France refused to extradite to the United States for murder, illustrating France's non-extradition policy for its nationals.

connections.description: Alleged co-conspirators in a scheme to identify, groom, and transport minor girls for sexual abuse.
Maxwell transferred millions of dollars in assets to Borgerson via trusts over five years, and he is a proposed co-signer on her bail package.
Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is the prosecuting attorney opposing Maxwell's release in this legal proceeding.

events.title: Bail Hearing and Detention Order
events.description: Court held a lengthy bail hearing and ordered Maxwell detained pending trial, finding her a serious flight risk.

events.title: Renewed Motion for Release
events.description: Maxwell's defense team filed a renewed motion for release on bail.

events.title: Alleged Criminal Scheme
events.description: The period during which Maxwell allegedly facilitated the sexual abuse of multiple minor victims by Jeffrey Epstein.

keyFacts: The government asserts Maxwell has approximately $22 million in assets, far more than the $3.8 million she initially reported to Pretrial Services.
France's Ministry of Justice confirmed in writing that France does not extradite its citizens to the United States, a significant concern given Maxwell's French citizenship.
Maxwell demonstrated an ability to live in hiding, using an alias, trusts, and isolated property in New Hampshire prior to her arrest.
Jeffrey Epstein's will includes a $10 million cash grant to Ghislaine Maxwell.
Multiple victims of the alleged abuse have provided statements urging the court to deny bail, fearing Maxwell will flee.
